title: Your First Credit Card
description: How to start your credit history from zero without falling into debt.

content.title: Secured vs. Unsecured
content.text: If you are new to Canada, banks may not give you a standard card yet. A 'Secured' card requires you to give the bank a deposit (e.g., $500), which becomes your credit limit. This is the safest and fastest way to prove you are reliable and start building your score.

content.title: The 21-Day Grace Period
content.text: In Canada, credit cards have a 'grace period' of at least 21 days. If you pay your ENTIRE statement balance by the due date, you pay $0 in interest. If you only pay the 'Minimum Payment,' the bank will charge you roughly 20-23% interest on everything you bought.

content.title: Credit is a Loan
content.text: Remember: A credit card is not extra money; it is a short-term loan. Every time you tap your card, the bank is watching. Paying on time every single month is the #1 factor (35% of your score) in building a great Canadian credit rating.

quiz.question: What is the main requirement for getting a 'Secured' credit card?
options: A cash deposit that acts as your collateral
A letter from your previous bank back home
quiz.explanation: A secured card requires a deposit (usually equal to your limit). This protects the bank while you prove you can manage credit responsibly.

quiz.question: How much interest do you pay if you pay your full balance every month before the due date?
quiz.explanation: As long as you pay the full statement balance during the grace period, you pay zero interest. This is the 'Golden Rule' of Canadian credit cards.
